Is this for the H2SO4 + 2NaOH? In which case what part of the calculation?
@ChadsPrep  yes! i’m just wondering since we have molarity for both and only one volume, why can’t we just do it M1V1 = M2V2? instead you did a mole to mole ratio?

M1V1 = M2V2 is used for dilutions where we take a solution with a certain number of moles and add water so we have the same number of moles of the same compound just with more water giving a lower value of M. In reaction stoichiometry we are using the coefficients to tell us the ratio of the moles that react for each substance. Here we have H2SO4 and 2NaOH reacting, so 1mole:2mole ratio. We can't use m1v1=m2v2 because the number of moles is not the same.
